title: Warn on close
description: When an issue being viewed in the detail pane is closed (by another user, another session, or auto-close), warn the user that the item has been closed. Currently there's no notification if an issue closes while you're viewing/editing it.
design:
## Approach
1. Poll the issue status periodically (every 2-5 seconds) while pane is open
2. When pane opens: store current issue.status
3. On poll: compare current status with stored status
4. If status changed to 'closed': show warning banner/toast in pane
5. Options in warning: "Reload", "Close pane", "Dismiss" 

Alternative: Use WebSocket (ws://localhost:8765) if available for real-time updates
acceptance_criteria:
- [ ] Polling implemented (or WebSocket if available)
- [ ] Warning shown when issue closes while pane is open
- [ ] Warning has clear message: "This issue has been closed"
- [ ] User can reload issue, close pane, or dismiss warning
- [ ] No polling when pane is not open (cleanup on close)
- [ ] Works when issue is closed by another session

title: Fix Svelte Warnings
description:
The Svelte compiler emits 24+ accessibility and CSS warnings when the dev server starts. These should be fixed to ensure the app is accessible and CSS is clean.

Key warnings:
- Interactive elements (menu, div with onclick) need tabindex and keyboard handlers
- Labels not associated with form controls
- Unused CSS selectors (~15 unused selectors in style block)
- Non-interactive elements with drag handlers need ARIA roles
design:
Fix warnings by:
1. Replace non-interactive elements that receive click events with proper elements (<button>, <a>, etc.)
2. For elements that must stay (divs with special styling), add role="button" and tabindex="0" and keyboard handlers
3. Associate form labels with inputs using htmlFor and id
4. Remove unused CSS selectors from the 5000+ line stylesheet
5. Add ARIA roles to drag-drop containers
acceptance_criteria:
- [ ] Zero Svelte compiler warnings on dev server startup
- [ ] All interactive elements are proper semantic elements or have ARIA roles
- [ ] All form labels are associated with controls
- [ ] All keyboard handlers present where onclick exists
- [ ] No unused CSS selectors in stylesheet
- [ ] Keyboard navigation still works (Tab through elements, Enter to activate)
notes:
CSS cleanup complete:
- Removed 4170 lines of duplicate CSS from +page.svelte
- Fixed empty ruleset warning in DetailPanel.svelte
- Added standard line-clamp property in IssueCard.svelte
- Fixed CSS variables inside media query
- Removed empty media queries

File sizes after cleanup:
- +page.svelte: 1678 lines (was 5535, 69% reduction)

Remaining warnings are accessibility issues (ARIA roles, keyboard handlers) - separate task.

Add attachments functionality
description:
Enable users to attach files (documents, images, screenshots, etc.) to issues. Attachments should be stored with the issue and be retrievable through the issue detail pane.

Current state: No attachment support exists. The Issue interface has no attachment field, and the Beads CLI may or may not support attachments natively.

!(use frontend design skill when working on this task)
design:
## Implementation Approach

1. **Verify Beads CLI Support**: Check if `bd` CLI has native attachment support (bd attach, bd list-attachments commands). If not, store attachments in `.beads/attachments/` directory.

2. **Data Model**: 
   - Add `attachments?: Attachment[]` to Issue interface in src/lib/types.ts
   - Attachment interface: { id, filename, size, mimetype, created_at, url }

3. **API Layer** (src/routes/api/issues/[id]/attachments/):
   - GET /[id]/attachments - List all attachments for an issue
   - POST /[id]/attachments - Upload new attachment (multipart/form-data)
   - DELETE /[id]/attachments/[filename] - Remove attachment

4. **Frontend** (src/routes/+page.svelte):
   - Add attachment section in pane-activity (below comments)
   - Show list of attachments with download links
   - Add file upload input with drag-and-drop support
   - Show file size and upload timestamp for each attachment
   - Delete button (with confirmation) for each attachment

5. **Storage**: Files stored in `.beads/attachments/{issue-id}/` with sanitized filenames

6. **UI Placement**: New "Attachments" section in the right pane, between the issue metadata and comments section
acceptance_criteria:
- [ ] Attachment interface added to types.ts
- [ ] GET endpoint returns list of attachments for an issue
- [ ] POST endpoint accepts file upload and stores in .beads/attachments/
- [ ] DELETE endpoint removes attachment from disk and Beads database
- [ ] Pane shows attachments list with filename, size, and timestamp
- [ ] Users can drag-drop files to upload
- [ ] Users can download attachments by clicking
- [ ] Users can delete attachments with confirmation dialog
- [ ] File size limit enforced (suggest 10MB per file)
- [ ] Only image MIME types show preview/thumbnail

title: Design improvements
description:
Visual system cleanup (biggest ROI)

Replace the heavy “glow/gradient everywhere” look with 3 surface levels:
App background (dark, flat) → Panel surface (slightly lighter) → Card surface (slightly lighter still).
Keep gradients only for hero areas (if any), not every container.

Standardize radius + borders + shadow:

One radius scale (e.g., 8 / 12 / 16).

One border style (1px, subtle, same alpha everywhere).

One shadow style (very soft) only on elevated items (modals, dragged cards).

Reserve strong color for state (Blocked/Done/Priority) and focus (active item). Everything else should be neutral.

Kanban board cards (readability + “less styling”)

Remove “one-sided border with rounded corners” entirely. Use:

Subtle full border + surface contrast, and a tiny status accent (2–4px top bar or a small dot).

Card content hierarchy:

Title (1–2 lines, strong)

Meta row (type • priority • age • assignee)

Tags row (cap at 2 + “+3”)

Footer icons (comments/attachments/subtasks) with consistent spacing

Make the column headers do more:

Count + WIP limit + quick filter chips (Assignee / Priority / Type)

Sticky headers while scrolling.

Ticket detail modal (the big one)

Add a clear layout: Header / Body / Footer

Header: Title + status pill + priority + quick actions (Edit, Copy link, Move, Archive/Delete)

Body: Tabs (Details | Comments | Activity | Attachments | Agent)

Comments: turn “No comments” into an empty state with a call to action and move the composer to a consistent spot (bottom of Comments tab).

Attachments: the large dashed dropzone dominates the modal—reduce it to a compact “Drop files” row + attachment list.

Add “Context strip” below the title: Project / Epic / Parent breadcrumbs and a quick link back to the board column.

Agent console/log UI (Grep/Read blocks)

Steps should be visually scannable:

Each step = compact header (icon + label + file count + duration) + collapsible body.

Highlight only the current step; everything else stays low-contrast.

Use a consistent code presentation:

Monospace, tighter line-height, clearer indentation, and a single background tone (avoid nested dark boxes inside dark boxes).

Put controls where people look:

Top-right: Pause/Resume, Clear, Copy session, “Open in side panel”.

Bottom: input with quick actions (Run, Stop, Attach context), plus a “/” hint.

“Agent windows” + “Chat windows” (avoid blocking the app)

Convert floating windows into a dockable drawer system:

Bottom drawer with tabs (Agents / Chat / Logs), resizable height.

Each agent session becomes a tab with unread indicators.

“Pop out” remains optional, but default is docked so it never covers the board/stats.

Add a Focus mode: one hotkey hides drawers + sidebars, leaving only the main view.

Buttons and CTAs (your “~5 styles” request)

Define exactly these (and use them everywhere):

Primary (main action): solid accent, high contrast

Secondary: subtle filled surface

Tertiary: outline

Ghost: text/icon only

Destructive: red accent (only for delete/wipe)
Then standardize states: hover, active, disabled, focus ring (important on dark UI). Avoid green-as-default; keep green strictly for “success/done”.
notes:
Summary: Implemented core design system cleanup with 3-tier surface levels, standardized tokens (radius 8/12/16, single border style, soft shadows for elevated only), 5-variant CTA button system, simplified card design with status dot accent, sticky column headers, and light theme support.

Commit: 7b3038d2026b653895fae2ecaf9d62f0a1799b47 style(beads-kanban-n5eh): design system cleanup and visual overhaul

Note: Some items from the original ticket (agent console UI, dockable drawer system, full modal tabs) were not implemented as they require more substantial changes. Created focused on highest-ROI visual system cleanup.

title: Improve card hotkey ui
description: The card hotkey UI overlay is overlapping elements and showing too much information. Current implementation shows all available keyboard shortcuts in an overlay that's cluttering the interface. The request is to simplify this - NOT to implement Vim keybindings (explicitly noted as "dont do vim").
design:
## Current Problem
The hotkey help overlay displays too much at once, overlaps cards, and disrupts the Kanban layout.

## Solution Options
1. **Hide by default**: Only show hotkey hints on hover/focus of cards (inline badges like "Press ? for help")
2. **Tooltip-based**: Show single hotkey tip on card hover (e.g., "Press Enter to edit")
3. **Compact cheat sheet**: Move hotkey reference to a footer bar instead of modal
4. **Context-sensitive**: Only show relevant hotkeys for the current element (fewer items)

Choose one approach and implement it without vim-mode features.
acceptance_criteria:
- [ ] Hotkey UI no longer overlaps cards
- [ ] Information displayed is reduced/simplified
- [ ] No vim keybindings implemented
- [ ] Keyboard navigation still functional
- [ ] Help still accessible (? key or menu)
